awd_titl_txt: CDI-TYPE II--COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Using Algebraic Topology to Connect Models with Measurements in Complex Nonequilibrium Systems
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In today's world, data are being gathered in nearly every sphere of human endeavour, in hopes that the data will lead to new insights and, thereby, improvements in the human condition.  Oftentimes, however,  the data are difficult to understand because the gathered data sets are very large and highly complex.   Thus, there is an urgent need to develop new tools to enable greater understanding of large complex sets of data. 

This project explored the development and use of new mathematical tools (from the branch of mathematics known as algebraic topology)  for gaining greater insight into data gathered in a particular setting; the turbulent flow of fluids driven by temperature variations.  This flow, called "turbulent convection", is a common experience---we all know hot, less dense air rises and colder more dense air falls---that's an example of turbulent convection; however, this type of flow shows up in many natural  settings (e.g., fluid motion in the ocean and atmosphere, weather forecasting) and technological applications (e.g., cooling of electronic devices, mixing in chemical processes).     Large data sets  were gathered from both laboratory experiments and computer simulations of turbulent convection.  It's important to note that while both the experiments and the simulations focused on the same flow problem, the complex, large data sets from experiments are different from the data sets from the computer because experiments can observe things that are hard to see in the computer simulations and vice versa.  Thus, providing ways to understand how the data from the lab and from the computer are connected is a key challenge.

There were two key scientific outcomes from this project.  First, we showed examples where new topology tools could be used to reduce the complexity of flows by readily identifying cases where flows that seemed to be different, were related by symmetry and, in effect, were the same flow.   Second, we found good evidence that different types of data for an important class of flows, called "plumes", might be related.  In particular, our work suggests a link between lab data on plume observations to computer data on plumes that might be used to predict and, perhaps, control plume formation.   Our results could be considered as a proof of principle that might suggest the new topology tools could be used for large data sets in situations other than fluid flows.

Additionally, the project provided  opportunities for training and professional development of three graduate students and one post-graduate researcher, specifically, developing  technical skills with dealing with large complex data sets  as well as developing  "soft skills" in the area of oral and written communication of highly technical content.
